docs.lead_paragraph: With Congress poised for final action on a major Medicare bill this week, some of the fiercest debate is focused on a section of the bill that prohibits the government from negotiating lower drug prices for the 40 million people on Medicare. That provision epitomizes much of the bill, which relies on insurance companies and private health plans to manage the new drug benefit. They could negotiate with drug companies, but the government, with much greater purchasing power, would be forbidden to do so.

headline.main: MEDICARE DEBATE TURNS TO PRICING OF DRUG BENEFITS

docs.abstract: Fiercest debate over Medicare bill will focus on section that would prohibit government from negotiating lower drug prices for 40 million people on Medicare; bill would allow private health plans to negotiate with drug companies, but government, with much greater purchasing power, would be forbidden to do so; supporters say it is necessary to prevent government from imposing price controls that could stifle innovation in pharmaceutical industry; critics say restriction would force government and Medicare beneficiaries to spend much more for drugs than they should; debate over bill continues in Senate, with Sen Edward M Kennedy saying he will lead filibuster against measure; other Democrats acknowledge they lack votes to sustain filibuster, but that they would use points of order to slow legislation, whose passage is priority for Pres Bush; photo (M)
docs.snippet: With Congress poised for final action on a major Medicare bill this week, some of the fiercest debate is focused on a section of the bill that prohibits the government from negotiating lower drug prices for the 40 million people on Medicare.    That...

docs.lead_paragraph: For any Senate majority leader, the final hours of a Congressional session are the clearest measure of success or failure, and no one knows that better than the physician from Tennessee who spent the weekend frantically arm-twisting and trolling for votes. Asked if the outcome of the year's two biggest bills could be considered a referendum on his first year as leader, Senator Bill Frist responded succinctly. ''Yes, if it goes well,'' he said. ''No, if it doesn't.''

headline.main: In Medicare Fight, Frist Is Scrambling To Improve Record

docs.abstract: Senate majority leader Bill Frist is poised to end term with .500 record on year's biggest issues, bills on energy policy and Medicare; spends weekend arm-twisting and lobbying for votes for new Medicare bill; is far less optimistic on fate of energy bill after Republicans fail by two votes to block Democratic filibuster on that bill; Frist, who employed contentious strategy of shutting out Democrats from preparation of energy bill, acknowledges that he does not know if he will succeed in efforts to get bill passed; Democrats claim that if Frist had been bit more accommodating to their wishes, he could easily have won votes on energy and Medicare without fight; photo (M)
docs.snippet: For any Senate majority leader, the final hours of a Congressional session are the clearest measure of success or failure, and no one knows that better than the physician from Tennessee who spent the weekend frantically arm-twisting and trolling for...

byline.original: By DAVID FIRESTONE; Sheryl Gay Stolberg contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: Kaiser Permanente in Oakland, Calif., the health maintenance organization, has narrowed to three finalists its review for a large new assignment, national brand agency for advertising. Spending for 2004 is estimated at $40 million. David Melancon, principal at Brandstream Partners in New York, which is managing the review, identified the finalists as three agencies of the Interpublic Group: Campbell-Ewald, Deutsch and McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising.

headline.main: Search by Kaiser Is Narrowed to Three

docs.abstract: Kaiser Permanente, health maintenance organization, narrows its review for large new assignment, national brand agency for advertising (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Cynthia Williams showed up nearly an hour before Howard Dean's scheduled appearance at Mount Olivet Baptist Church in Harlem yesterday morning, eager to disappear among the women in feathered hats who filled the pews. For once, the only thing making Ms. Williams, an African-American computer technician from Nutley, N.J., stand out was the blue Dean button on her lapel. ''So many events that I go to I'm like one of maybe two black faces,'' said Ms. Williams, 37, a staunch Dean fan who has followed her candidate to more than a dozen events in New York, New Jersey and New Hampshire over the last year. ''The only thing I can say the reason why is there hasn't been any effort to reach out to minorities.''

headline.main: Dean's New Challenge: Reaching Out to Black Voters

docs.abstract: Howard Dean's presidential campaign faces challenge of reaching out to black voters; has called attention to support it has won from several leading black politicians and two major unions with many African-American and Hispanic members; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: STOCKING shelves and hauling boxes on the graveyard shift at Target was something Ed Marx never imagined he would be doing. After 27 years as a computer programmer, Mr. Marx said, he thought his technology skills ensured he would be employed in that field for many years. It has not turned out that way. In August 2002, Mr. Marx, 49, lost his job at the Computer Sciences Corporation, a technology contractor and services company in Moorestown, N.J. Mr. Marx and his company say he was a victim of offshore outsourcing, known as offshoring. Unable, so far, to find a full-time job in his field, he has been working at Target since September.

headline.main: Tech Workers Struggle To Answer Overseas Threat

docs.abstract: Shifting of information technology jobs overseas costs jobs of Americans like Ed Marx, computer programmerr with 27 years of experience who finds himself working at Target; photo; other American technology workers report they are offered lower salaries as result of offshore contracting (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I've long wondered why employers should furnish health insurance when the large majority of illnesses and injuries have nothing to do with employment. A single-payer plan would seem to make more sense, but that probably hasn't been popular because conservatives have maligned ''socialized medicine.''

headline.main: Health Insurance, But Provided by Whom?

docs.abstract: Gary Box letter on Daniel Akst's Nov 2 article questions why employers should provide health insurance

headline.main: Health Insurance, But Provided by Whom?

docs.lead_paragraph: A fiercely polarized House approved legislation on Saturday that would add prescription drug benefits to Medicare, after an all-night session and an extraordinary bout of Republican arm-twisting to muster a majority. The Senate opened its debate under threat of a filibuster. The final version of the bill, a compromise worked out by House and Senate negotiators, was adopted in the House by a vote of 220 to 215. But a roll-call vote, which rarely exceeds 20 minutes, began at 3 a.m. and was held open for nearly three hours, as Republican leaders and Bush administration officials scrambled to quell a conservative rebellion.

headline.main: SHARPLY SPLIT, HOUSE PASSES BROAD MEDICARE OVERHAUL; FORCEFUL LOBBYING BY BUSH
headline.kicker: A FINAL PUSH IN CONGRESS: THE OVERVIEW

docs.abstract: Bill that would add drug benefits to Medicare is approved by sharply split House, 220 to 215, in predawn vote following extraordinary bout of Republican arm-twisting; Democrats overwhelmingly oppose legislation, as do some conservative Republicans; bill calls for biggest changes in Medicare since its creation in 1965; it seeks to expand Medicare's benefits while making program more cost efficient; it offers new drug benefit to 40 million elderly and disabled Americans covered by Medicare in 2006; Senate begins considering bill hours after House vote, under threat of filibuster by Sen Edward M Kennedy, who says Sen John Kerry would return from his presidential campaign to join filibuster effort; fellow Democratic Sen Jack Reed calls bill 'bait and switch' effort by Republicans to begin to unravel Medicare; bill would substantially expand role of private health plans by providing billions of dollars in new federal subsidies; it would also create new tax incentives for people of all ages to set aside money in savings accounts for their own medical expenses; Democrats claim bill would force Medicare to compete with private plans that would be heavily subsidized by federal government and would cherry-pick healthiest recipients; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A fiercely polarized House approved legislation on Saturday that would add prescription drug benefits to Medicare, after an all-night session and an extraordinary bout of Republican arm-twisting to muster a majority. The Senate opened its debate...

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and ROBIN TONER; Carl Hulse contributed reporting for this article

docs.lead_paragraph: As President Bush flew over the North Atlantic on Friday, heading home from three days as the houseguest of Queen Elizabeth, he switched his attention from the glamour of royal Britain to the grit of American politics. From Air Force One, with his politically critical Medicare bill in precarious straits on Capitol Hill, Mr. Bush placed calls to pressure wavering House Republicans. Karl Rove, Mr. Bush's chief political aide, had already made calls from Buckingham Palace, House Republicans said.

headline.main: For White House, 2 Bills Offer Route to Political High Ground
headline.kicker: A FINAL PUSH IN CONGRESS: THE WHITE HOUSE

docs.abstract: Pres Bush, en route home from England on Air Force One, places calls to pressure wavering House Republicans to vote for politically critical Medicare bill; after returning to Washington he keeps up pressure on Congress to pass bill in his weekly radio address; Bush aides have mounted yearlong effort to get Medicare and energy bills passed before heavy politicking begins, so Bush can focus on national security and economy as chief issues of his re-election campaign; Medicare and energy bills would help Bush's appeal to two crucial constituencies, elderly and Republican big-business class; Republicans hope Medicare bill would allow Bush to make inroads with voters on issue Democrats had long considered their own; Democrats say bill is stuffed with giveaways to drug and insurance companies and that in the end it would cut benefits to old people it is designed to help; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: OUR lives are held together by an unseen net, a complex weave of everything it takes to get us through each day. With only a small tear here, or a frayed spot there, the pieces of life begin to fall. Janet Ray Kalson knows this. She is a lawyer for MFY Legal Services, which represents the poor and disabled of New York City. The office runs a Workplace Justice Project, among other things, which helps workers get the rights and benefits they are due by law. Every day, Ms. Kalson sees how easily a life can unravel when something seemingly small goes wrong. But she didn't fully see the knots and moorings of her own life until last month.

headline.main: Paycheck Goes, and the Dominoes Fall

docs.abstract: Life's Work column on Janet Ray Kalson, lawyer for MFY Legal Services in New York; Kalson discusses falling dominoes of her family life since office went on strike in October, particularly need to hold onto baby-sitter (M)
